message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the properties of matter. When a brick is liquefied, it undergoes a physical change from a solid to a liquid state. The weight of the brick remains the same because weight is not dependent on the state of matter. Option (A) is incorrect because liquefying a brick does not involve electricity. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight does not change. Option (D) is incorrect because the brick still exists, just in a different state.

This question tests our understanding of the concept of weight and the physical properties of matter. When a brick is liquefied, it undergoes a change in state from a solid to a liquid. However, the weight of the brick remains the same because weight is determined by the mass of an object and the acceleration due to gravity, both of which do not change when the state of matter changes. Option (A) is incorrect because electrification refers to the process of charging an object with electricity, which is not relevant to the weight of the brick. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight remains the same even though the brick has changed in state. Option (D) is incorrect because the weight is not removed; it remains the same.

This question requires understanding of the properties of matter. When a brick is liquefied, it changes from a solid state to a liquid state but its mass and weight remain the same. Option (A) is incorrect because liquefying a brick does not involve electricity. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight of the brick does not change when it is liquefied. Option (D) is incorrect because the brick still exists, even in its liquid state, so it is not removed. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer because the weight of the brick remains static.

This question requires a basic understanding of the physical properties of matter. When a brick is liquefied, it changes from a solid state to a liquid state but its weight remains the same. The weight of an object is determined by its mass, which remains constant regardless of its state of matter. Option (A) is incorrect because liquefaction does not involve electricity. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight does not change. Option (D) is incorrect because the weight is not removed, it is simply unchanged.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the principles of matter and weight. When a brick is liquefied, it undergoes a physical change from a solid to a liquid state, but its weight remains the same. Weight is a measure of the force of gravity acting on an object, and this force is determined by the mass of the object. Even though the physical form of the brick may have changed, its mass (and therefore its weight) remains constant. Option (A) is incorrect because liquefying a brick does not generate electricity. Option (C) is also incorrect because the weight of the brick does not change. Option (D) is incorrect because the brick does not disappear or have its weight removed when it is liquified.

The weight of the brick remains the same because weight is a measure of the force exerted on an object due to gravity, and this force does not change when the physical state of the object changes. Option (A) is incorrect because electrification has no direct relationship to the weight of an object. Option (C) is also incorrect because the weight of the brick remains constant. Option (D) is incorrect because the weight of the brick is not removed, it simply remains the same.

Option (A) is incorrect because liquefying a brick does not result in electrification. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight of the brick does not change when it is liquefied. Option (D) is incorrect because the weight of the brick is not removed when it is liquefied.

Option (A) is incorrect because liquefying a brick does not involve the introduction of electricity. Option (C) is incorrect because the weight of the brick remains constant.
